ol.li: Give a set that is closed under scalar multiplication but not addition.
Give a set closed under addition but not scalar multiplication.
Give a set closed under neither.
The union of the x-axis and the y-axis in \R^2 is one.
The set of integers, as a subset of \R^1, is one.
The subset \left\{\vec{v}\right\} of \R^2 is one, where \vec{v} is any nonzero vector.

statement.p:
True or false.
The solution set to any consistent system of linear equations is a subspace.
The solution set to a consistent system of linear equations of the form Ax=0 is a subspace.
The set of points where two subspaces meet (i.e., the collection of points that are in both subspaces) is a subspace. For example, consider the set of points that lie on the intersection of two planes, or on a plane and a line.
Given any two subspaces V and W, the collection of points that are in one or both of V or W is a subspace. For example, the collection of points on either or both of the lines y=x and y=-x is the cross-shaped X, and includes their intersection point at the origin.
If A is a square matrix and the equation Ax=0 has only the trivial solution x=0, then the equation Ax=b has a solution for every appropriately-sized vector b .

ol.li: False. For example, the solution set of the set of equations x+y=3 in \R^2 is a line, but doesn't pass through the origin.

True. Here, we can check the axioms in the definition of a subspace. Given the shape of the equation Ax=0, we clearly have that the zero vector solves this equation, and so the solution set contains the origin (which solves the problem encountered in the last example). Now, suppose that x and y are solutions. Then A(x+y)=Ax+Ay=0+0=0, and so x+y also solves the system, and for a real number \alpha, A(\alpha x)=\alpha Ax=\alpha0=0, and so \alpha x is a solution too. Thus, the solution set satisfies parts 2 and 3 of the definition of a subspace, and hence is a subspace.

True. Suppose that V and W are both subspaces of \R^n. Then we can check each part of the definition is satisfied by the set of points where V and W meet. Firstly, since 0 is in both subspaces, its in this new set, so it is a nonempty set. Furthermore, if x and y are in the set and \alpha is a real number, then \alpha x+y is in the set, using the axioms in the definition of subspace applied twice, once using the fact that x and y are in particular both in V , and once using that they are both in W. Note that this implies both the second and third parts of the definition of subspace, as we can take \alpha=1 for part 2 of the definition, and choose y=0 for part 3 of the definition.

False. Although this always contains the origin, it will usually not be a subspace. For instance, consider the two lines y=\pm x in \R^2. The collection of points in one or both of these lines is not closed under addition. To see this, we just need a counter example. For instance, choose (1, -1) on the line y=-x and the point (2, 2) on the line y=x. In particular, both of these points are on the X figure. However, the sum of these two points, (1,-1)+(2,2)=(3,-1), is not on either of the two lines, as 3\neq\pm(-1).

True. By the Rank Theorem, the equation Ax=0 (which is consistent, as it automatically has the solution x=0 gives rise to an equation (dimension of column span) + (dimension of solution set)= number of variables, say n. The question postulates that the dimension of the solution set is 0 (it is just the point at the origin), and so the dimension of the column span is n. Thus, every vector in \R^n is a linear combination of the columns of A, i.e., the equation Ax=b has a solution for every n-dimensional vector b.

The column space of A contains all linear combinations of the columns of A, which are precisely the vectors of the form Ax for an arbitrary vector x. Thus Ax=b has a solution if and only if b is in the column space of A.

\Col(A) is a plane in \R^3 given by all combinations of the pivot columns, namely
c_1 \cdot \vec{1 3 0} + c_2 \cdot \vec{2 8 4}

statement.p:
Let A be a 2 \times 2 matrix such that \Nul(A) is the line y=x. Let b be a nonzero vector in \R^2. Which of the following are definitely not the solution set of Ax = b?
The line y=x.
The y-axis.
The line y=x+1.
The set \left\{0\right\}.
The empty set.

answer.p: 1, 2, and 4. The solution set of Ax = b is either empty or a translate of \Nul(A) by a nonzero vector, namely, a specific solution to Ax = b.

statement.p: If A is a 3 \times 3 matrix, is it possible that \Col(A) = \Nul(A)?
[MIT OCW] If \Col(B) is a subspace of \Nul(A), then either (choose one) AB or BA must be simply .

answer.p: AB=0. The reason is that for any vector x, Bx \in \Col(B) \subseteq \Nul(A), so ABx=0. But the only way ABx=0 for all x can be true is if AB=0.

statement.p:
[MIT OCW] Suppose A and B are 3 \times 3 matrices.
If a vector v is in the column space of AB, why is v also in the column space of A?
Give an example of A and B so that \Col(AB) is smaller than \Col(A).
If a vector v is in the column space of AB, this does not necessarily mean it is in the column space of B. Give an example of A and B and a vector v that is in \Col(AB) but not \Col(B).

ol.li: v being in the column space of AB means that there is an x such that ABx=v. But then if we take y=Bx, then Ay=ABx=v, so v is in the column space of A.
If we take A=\mat{1 0 0;0 0 0;0 0 0} and B=\mat{0 0 0;0 0 0;0 0 1}, then AB=0, so its column space is Z(only the zero is the vector), but the column space of A is the line through \vec{1 0 0}.

We can take A to be the 3 \times 3 matrix that permutes the first two coordinates, so A=\mat{0 1 0;1 0 0;0 0 1} Then if C(B) is a line generated by \vec{1 0 0}, then \Col(AB) is generated by \vec{0 1 0}. So we can take A=\mat{0 1 0;1 0 0;0 0 1}, B=\mat{1 1 1; 0 0 0;0 0 0}, and v=\vec{0 1 0}.

statement.p: [MIT OCW] Suppose the matrices A and B have the same column space. Give an example where A and B have different nullspaces - or reason why this is impossible.

answer.p: The simplest way to provide an example is to add dependent columns to matrix A. For example, matrices \mat{1} and \mat{1 0} have the same column space and different null spaces.

statement.p: [MIT OCW] If B is a square matrix then \Col(B) = \Col(B^T). True or False.

answer.p: False. Consider B=\mat{0 1; 0 0}. Then the column space of B is \vec{1 0} and the column space of B^T is \vec{0 1}.

statement.p:
[MIT OCW]
Suppose you are given nonzero column vectors r,n,c,l \in \R^2. Explain how to determine if these vectors can form bases for the 4 fundamental subspaces, row space, nullspace, column space and left nullspace respectively, and output a matrix with those 4 fundamental subspaces if possible. Hint: Think about orthogonality of the four subspaces. Express matrix in terms of the vectors above.
Suppose you are given 4 matrices whose columns are all vectors in \R^{10}. R=\mat{r_1 r_2 \ldots, r_i}, N = \mat{n_1 n_2 \ldots, n_j}, C=\mat{c_1 c_2 \ldots, c_i}, L=\mat{l_1 l_2 \ldots, l_n}. The columns of R form a basis for the row space, the columns of N form a basis for the nullspace, the columns of C form a basis for the column space, and the columns of L form a basis for the left nullspace. Explain how to determine if these vectors form the basis for the four fundamental subspaces, ad output a matrix that has those four subspaces.

ol.li: By the orthogonality of the fundamental subspaces, we must have r \cdot n = r^T \cdot n =0, c \cdot l = c^T \cdot l = 0. If the 4 column vectors satisfies the above condition, A=cr^T is a matrix satisfies the condition.

Use the same idea above. By the orthogonality of the fundamental subspaces, we must have R^T N=0, C^T L=0. e also need the dimension to match, i.e. i+j = i+n = 10. Under the condition above, A=CR^T is a matrix satisfies the condition.
